body: have you tried the --depends option? not json, but it is a list of the files

It raises "option --depends requires an output path to be specified" instead of sending the response to stdout as help especifies

Is this a bug or I miss something?
Sorry, I don't understand, please cab you explain that last comment?

If I run lessc with nodejs without any parameter it returns the list of argumens and I found:
-M, --depends            Output a makefile import dependency list to stdout

But the error sugests that I have to specify a path to put the make file? instead of returning this file to stdout as help points

What I'm missing?

Thanks a lot!
Yes that's right because the dependency goes to stdout too
So what's the point with the error?

You need to write the css to a file in order to see the depends on stdout.
Do you need the css on stdout? Do you need the list I'd depends in a file?
If it were in a file would it solve your usecase?

No, sorry!
I'm calling nodejs + lessc from python via popen so I capture the stdout, cache the response and the return it
The idea is to cache the paths to the actual imports for invalidation

This is why I'm hoping for a json response

Or if you prefer to implement the cache system in lessc...
The point is that I work a lot in memory so need to have a cache system

Don't care if I have to implement it by my self or this library plans to solve this issues by itself but in case I would implement it I will vote for, at least, a way to return the css + the paths for the imports

I'm also experiencing this issue. The command seems broken.

It claims: 

```
 --depends            Outputs a makefile import dependency list to stdout.
```

But specifying that option simply throws the following error:

```
option --depends requires an output path to be specified
```

Are we misunderstanding the function or is this a bug?

---

If I specify an output file as suggested, lessc just outputs the file I specified in the format

``` bash
$FILE: 
```

No compiled code, or makefile dependency list.

It appears broken.

lessc --depends in.less out.css

Does something but it doesnt seem to output the paths

Additionally, would it be possible to generate a dependency tree without actually parsing the Less (i.e., just generating the paths).

The reason I ask is because I've set up an automatic build system that compiles the Less files to CSS on the fly. The way it works is fairly simple:
1. Check modification time on all .less files for a given HTTP request.
2. Loop through all required less files, keeping track of latest mod time.
3. Compare the last mod time to the mod time on the cached file.
4. If there is a change, then trigger the rebuild process (i.e., call lessc).

This way, the build process is all server side, and our developers can just share the Less compiler sitting on our dev box.

This is easy to maintain as long as the less follows a very specific folder structure, like app/less/$section/*.less. But it isn't always that simple... less imports can call code from many different locations.

The problem I see is that it  would be expensive to check dependencies **and** compile the code. Is it currently possible to allow simple generating a dependency tree without lots of re-factoring? I'll dig into the code myself, if it doesn't take too much.

I see. I didn't know that you can use variables in imports or within mixins (I've only been using Less for about 3-4 months).

Why I think this sort of build system is highly desirable -- all a developer has to do is go into his / her editor (vi, Sublime, emacs, ed, etc.,), save the code and reload the browser. Then, they see the new CSS right away, without having to muck about in their favorite editor's settings.

Since the tree can only be derived after parsing the Less, maybe it makes more sense to cache the dependency trees in my build system, and check for code changes that way.

---

In a worst case scenario, there's always the button to nuke the cached css files so that a rebuild is forced.

It would be nice to see the dependency tree option fixed. Would be glad to help in any way I can.

@avindra If understand your ideas correctly we usually solve this kind of problems using things like `grunt-contrib-watch` (and similar/related tools for `grunt`, `gulp` etc.). I.e. I just press "save" in my favorite editor and _everything_ else is done totally automatically (The only needed thing is to configure what files to watch but this usually is no more than just two or tree dirs with Less files even for complex projects). Also, normally recompiling the whole stuff is actually quite fast process (for instance a pretty huge Bootstrap based project is compiled for less then a second which in most cases is still faster than reloading even empty HTML page in a browser).
I just took a look into grunt and the watcher last night. It looks like a good alternative to what I'm doing. I try not to reinvent the wheel, looks like I messed up here. :cry:
I am going to fix the depends option and by doing that less will expose a list of imports as one of its results, allowing people to programatically get the imports that have been included.
